Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Genetic and Biochemical Dissection of Plant Sulfate Transceptor
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal is to understand how plants sense their nutritional status with respect to the macronutrient sulfur (S). Plants are able to adjust their growth and physiology in response to the level of mineral nutrients available to them in soil. When nutrient level is low they become more efficient at nutrient utilization. Very little is known about how plants sense nutrients or even what exactly is sensed. The current project could set the stage for improving nutrient use efficiency thereby reducing the input costs and environmental impact associated with the use of fertilizers in agriculture.

A forward genetic approach has been used to identify a gene that is involved in S-sensing in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The project will use both genetic and molecular approaches to understand how the sensor functions. What is learned will be a breakthrough not only for the field of plant S-nutrition, but also for the larger field of nutrient receptors. The results from these activities will be disseminated at symposia, conferences and in journal publications. The genetic resources generated by the project will be made available to the research community.

This is a collaborative project between two institutions, Lehman College of the City University of New York, a federally designated Hispanic Institution, and Rutgers University. The project will recruit minority undergraduate students and high school teachers to participate in research at both institutions through an active exchange program. The aim is to use a provocative research project to stimulate the interest of students from minority groups to pursue careers in plant biology and to enhance the US competitiveness in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Sulfur (S) is an essential mineral for life. Plants must acquire S for growth and they do so through their roots. However, S is not always available. When it is in short supply plants are able to sense the limitation and adapt to it. The basis for adaptation is the regulation of genes that control plant growth and development. What was not known, and was the focus of the current project, is how plants sense S and how the information is transmitted to regulate genes. By screening mutant variants of the genetic model plant Arabidopsis thaliana that inappropriately express an S-response gene (Fig. 1) a candidate for the S sensor was discovered. The S-sensor is a well-studied high-affinity sulfate transporter called SULTR1;2, which is known to be responsible for transport of S into roots. Based on a series of experiments we deduced that SULTR1;2 must have two functions, one in S transport and the other S sensing. The way in which it carries out both functions is still unknown; however, the evidence indicates that transport is a separate function from sensing, meaning that the ability to sense S is not dependent on whether SULTR1;2 is pumping S into cells. Other evidence reveals that SULTR1;2 cannot be the only sensor of S and that the mechanism by which plants detect this mineral is more complex than initially thought.

Understanding how plants adapt to S-nutrient level is of fundamental importance and has strong implications for agriculture. In order to achieve production levels necessary to feed a world population of about 7.5 billion people, it is necessary to apply mineral nutrients in the form of fertilizers. But what plants do not absorb causes severe environmental problems. For this reason scientists are striving to improve the efficiency of nutrient utilization. The current project is one key step toward that goal.

Another significant impact of the work is that we identified a dual function nutrient transporter and sensor. A few such proteins have recently been discovered and have been coined transceptors. They are known from organisms ranging from yeast to plants and humans. It has been proposed that nutrient sensors may have evolved from transporters and transceptors are considered an evolutionary intermediate between classical sensors and transporters. How transcpetors function and how they evolved is a central question for future research to which the current project has contributed.

Broader Impacts

The team working on this project included scientists from Rutgers University, a major state university; and Lehman College of the City University of New York, a public four-year college serving about 1.2 million people in the Bronx, an ethnically diverse and economically underdeveloped borough of New York. The partnership provided premier undergraduate scientific experiences for students from underrepresented demographics as well as graduate students and postdocs. Inter-university collaborations have become increasingly important as biology has developed into a complex activity requiring scientists with diverse expertise. In addition, it has become an ever greater priority to increase the diversity of the scientific workforce. The current project had an impact on both areas of the scientific research enterprise.
